column2: COVID-19 negative certification required for entering the country. From 1 April 2022, travellers who have recovered from COVID-19 in the past 90 days will be exempted from providing a negative COVID-19 RT PCR test. Upon arriving in Brunei, travellers must take an Antigen Rapid Test (ART) (lateral flow) and another COVID-19 RT PCR test on day 5.
column3:
Quarantine requirement at government designated site. From 1 April 2022, travellers who have recovered from COVID-19 in the past 90 days will be exempted from undergoing mandatory quarantine. They must provide proof of recovery from COVID-19 in the past 90 days.
Travellers who have completed their second dose of the COVID-19 vaccination will only be required to quarantine between 1 to 7 days, depending on the country they departed from. Their second dose of the vaccine must be obtained more than 14 days from the date of arrival into Brunei.
column5:
Latest News:

International Resrictions:
*Entry to Brunei: Entry to Brunei is restricted. Land and sea borders are currently closed. On 30 March 2022, Brunei announced changes for inbound and outbound travellers.
*Entry from a Travel Green Listed Country: From 1 April 2022, non-essential travel will be permitted to and from Travel Green list countries; Australia, Cambodia, China, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia (air travel only), New Zealand, Singapore, United Kingdom, United Arab Emirates and Saudi Arabia. Upon arriving in Brunei, travellers from a Travel Green List country must take an Antigen Rapid Test (ART) (lateral flow) and a COVID-19 RT PCR test, and self-isolate until you have received a negative result (see Quarantine). You must take an additional (self-administered) ART on Day 2 and Day 3 and upload the results on the BruHealth App (your day of arrival is considered Day 1).
*Entry from a non-green list country: Only essential travel is allowed from countries not listed under the Travel Green list and you must apply for an Entry Travel Pass from the Prime Minister’s Office at least 8 working days before the intended date of travel. See the Brunei Prime Minister’s Office (PMO) website for further information, or nearest Brunei embassyhere.
Travellers from countries not listed under the Travel Green list must take an ART upon arrival and then self-isolate (see Quarantine). You must undergo a COVID-19 RT-PCR test on Day 5 at a designated swab centre (day of arrival is considered Day 1). COVID-19 recovered travellers are only required to undergo ART upon arrival (at a fee of B$20.00).
All travellers into Brunei must:
• be fully vaccinated unless they can show proof of a medical exemption from having the COVID-19 vaccination (under 18s travelling with a group of vaccinated adults will follow the vaccinated protocols).
• submit an Arrival Declaration form on the Brunei Prime Minister’s Office (PMO) website no more than 24 hours prior to departure.
• download and register on the BruHealth App prior to departure (see Data Collection).
• make payment for the post arrival RT-PCR test and ART ($100) and obtain a payment receipt which states the name and passport number of the traveller. (NB, those who have recently recovered from COVID-19 and have a recovery certificate need only do an ART on arrival).
• show to their airline at check-in a negative COVID-19 RT PCR test obtained within 48 hours of departure or an ART obtained within 24 hours of departure.
Foreign nationals entering Brunei for a short visit (less than 90 days) are required to obtain a Travel Medical Insurance with COVID-19 coverage (a minimum coverage of $50,000 BND). Foreign nationals entering for the purpose of employment, studying or as eligible dependent are exempted.
From 1 October 2020, all travellers entering Brunei via a land border will need to pay $3 BND per person on exit and $3 BND on return or entry. You should refer to the Brunei Prime Minister’s Office (PMO) website for the latest information.
*Travellers who have recently had COVID: From 1 April 2022, travellers who have recovered from COVID-19 in the past 90 days will be exempted from providing a negative COVID-19 RT PCR test on arrival. They must provide proof of recovery from COVID-19 in the past 90 days.
*Demonstrating your COVID-19 status: Brunei will accept proof of COVID-19 recovery and vaccination record. *Quarantine requirements: Fully vaccinated visitors to Brunei from Travel Green List countries must undergo self-isolation at a suitable accommodation (home residence or hotel accommodation) until you receive a negative result for the post arrival RT-PCR test.
Vaccinated travellers from countries not listed under the Travel Green list must undergo quarantine at a suitable accommodation (home residence or hotel) until you receive a negative result for the post arrival RT-PCR test taken on Day 5.
From 1 April 2022, travellers who have recovered from COVID-19 in the past 90 days will be exempted from undergoing mandatory self-isolation. They must provide proof of recovery from COVID-19 in the past 90 days.
*Data collection: On arrival in Brunei, it is mandatory to use the BruHealth app to record test results, record your health status on a daily basis and to enter public buildings and events where you need to scan a QR code. Failure to do so may result in financial penalties and legal repercussions, additionally you not being able to access public buildings.
*Exiting Brunei: From 1 April 2022, travellers exiting Brunei (for any destination) no longer require a travel permit. Residents and expatriate workers (green identity card holders) who wish to travel are required to be fully vaccinated against COVID-19, with the second dose administered not more than 3 months prior to departure or have received a booster dose. Unvaccinated passengers will only be permitted to travel if they have a certificate of medical exemption from vaccination or of having recovered from COVID in the past 90 days.
Brunei citizens and permanent residents are required to obtain a Travel Medical Insurance with COVID-19 coverage (a minimum coverage of $50,000 BND) valid for the entire duration of their travel.
From 1 October 2020, all travellers exiting Brunei via a land border will need to pay $3 BND per person on exit and $3 BND on return or entry. A permit for land border travel is still banned and will require a special permit. You should refer to the Brunei Prime Minister’s Office (PMO) website for the latest information.

Internal Restrictions:
*Coronavirus lockdown: Brunei went into lockdown on 7 August 2021. Although measures have since relaxed, there are still restrictions in place.
As part of Brunei’s National COVID-19 Recovery Framework, Brunei moved to its “early endemic phase” on 15 December until 15 April 2022. Business premises including restaurants, fitness facilities, markets and cinemas can open at 75% capacity or 300 people, whichever is the lower number. Social gatherings at home are limited to 30 people only, and all attendees must take an Antigen Rapid Test (ART).
With the rise of Omicron in March, schools moved back to online learning with some exemptions granted for key exam years. The Brunei Government announced on 28 March 2022 that child care centres, kindergartens, secondary schools, colleges and sixth form centres will resume classroom learning on 5 April.
Primary schools with less than 50 pupils have been allowed to reopen. On 2 April, they announced that all primary schools will resume classroom learning on 14 May 2022. All international schools have been given exemptions and have resumed classroom learning on 12 April 2022. Students must take an ART three times a week.
All individuals, regardless of vaccination status will be allowed to enter public premises and government offices and attend private and public events. Unvaccinated adults must take an ART, the results of which will be valid for 2 days. Unvaccinated under 18s will be exempt from taking an ART test if they are accompanied by a fully vaccinated adult. Brunei will accept the proof of COVID-19 recovery and vaccination record. Your appointment card from vaccination centres is not designed to be used as proof of vaccination and should not be used to demonstrate your vaccine status.
You should expect to have your temperature taken, electronically, and must check-in to business premises and government offices using the BruHealth app. Masks are mandatory for everyone over 2 years old when in public places, but may be removed when you are drinking or eating, or if you are exercising. There are financial penalties for not adhering to mask guidelines.
Foreign people travelling should check the Brunei Ministry of Health and the Prime Ministers Office websites for up to date guidance, policy on travel to/from Brunei and details on how to download and use the BruHealth app. *If you test positive for COVID-19, you may need to stay where you are until you test negative. You may also need to seek treatment there.
